missed.title: SQL Injection in Category Filter
missed.reason: The expected SQL injection vulnerability in the category filter (index.php, lines 44-46) was not discovered during the penetration test. The actual findings focus on WebSocket security, file system access, and missing authentication mechanisms, but do not include any analysis of the PHP application logic or SQL query handling in the category filter. This suggests either the SQL injection testing was not performed, the vulnerable code path was not executed during testing, or the testing methodology did not include traditional web application vulnerability scanning (e.g., SQLmap or manual SQL injection testing).

extra.title: Missing Security Headers in All Responses
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application lacks critical HTTP security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security, X-XSS-Protection). This is a valid finding indicating missing defense-in-depth security controls.

extra.title: Unauthenticated Arbitrary Command Execution via WebSocket
extra.assessment: New discovery - A critical vulnerability allowing arbitrary command execution on the WebSocket endpoint without authentication. This represents complete system compromise capability.

extra.title: Denial of Service via Connection Exhaustion - No Connection Limits
extra.assessment: New discovery - The WebSocket endpoint accepts unlimited concurrent connections without enforcement of connection limits or rate limiting, enabling resource exhaustion attacks.

extra.title: No Accessible Endpoints - Complete Application Lockdown
extra.assessment: New discovery - The HTTP application returns 404 for all requests regardless of path or method. This indicates either misconfiguration, incomplete deployment, or an intentional lockdown of the HTTP interface.

extra.title: No Rate Limiting on WebSocket Messages - DoS via Message Flooding
extra.assessment: New discovery - Individual WebSocket connections can send unlimited messages per second without rate limiting, enabling message flooding denial of service attacks.

extra.title: Unencrypted WebSocket Communication - Plain Text Transmission
extra.assessment: New discovery - The WebSocket service only accepts unencrypted ws:// connections instead of requiring wss:// (WebSocket Secure), allowing MITM attacks and eavesdropping on all communications.

extra.title: Authentication Bypass - Unauthenticated Access to Web Terminal
extra.assessment: New discovery - The Web Terminal interface is accessible without any authentication, allowing unauthenticated users to interact with the terminal interface.

extra.title: Unauthorized Privilege Escalation to Root via Sudo NOPASSWD
extra.assessment: New discovery - The daytona user is misconfigured with '(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL' sudo privileges, allowing any command execution as root without password verification. Combined with WebSocket RCE, this creates complete root compromise.

extra.title: Unrestricted Directory Traversal and Local File System Enumeration
extra.assessment: New discovery - The /files/ endpoint allows unauthenticated directory traversal and enumeration of the entire filesystem structure, enabling reconnaissance for further attacks.

extra.title: Application Version Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - Version information (0.0.0-dev) is exposed via unauthenticated endpoint, revealing development status and enabling targeted vulnerability research based on specific version.

extra.title: Unrestricted Unauthenticated File Deletion Vulnerability
extra.assessment: New discovery - The /files/ endpoint accepts unauthenticated DELETE requests allowing arbitrary file deletion throughout the filesystem with application process permissions.

extra.title: SSH Protocol Denial of Service via Oversized Packet Length Field
extra.assessment: New discovery - The SSH service is vulnerable to DoS attacks when receiving packets with oversized length fields, causing indefinite hangs and resource exhaustion.
